unnormalised: Cybersecurity, yaar, it’s not just for the IT walas anymore, right? It’s like, everyone needs to be clued in, from your dadi using WhatsApp to your bhai running a small business. Because seriously, the cyber crooks are getting smarter than ever. Think of them as the Bollywood villains of the digital age, always plotting something sneaky.

Because seriously, the cyber crooks are getting smarter than ever. Think of them as the Bollywood villains of the digital age, always plotting something sneaky.

unnormalised: I mean, remember that ransomware attack on the hospital last year? All their patient data was locked up until they paid a hefty ransom. That’s not just some tech problem, that’s a serious real-world issue! And it's not just big companies. Small businesses are getting hit all the time. That cafe down the street that accepts UPI payments? They could be vulnerable if their POS system isn’t secured properly.

That cafe down the street that accepts U-P-I payments? They could be vulnerable if their P-O-S system isn't secured properly.

unnormalised: So, what can you do? Well, first off, strong passwords, my friend. I'm talking proper strong! Not your birthday (15/08/1947) or your pet’s name. Think complex, with a mix of uppercase, lowercase, numbers (like 12345) and symbols. And don't reuse them across different accounts! A password manager is your best friend here.
normalised: So, what can you do? Well, first off, strong passwords, my friend. I'm talking proper strong! Not your birthday (fifteenth august nineteen forty seven) or your pet's name. Think complex, with a mix of uppercase, lowercase, numbers (like one two three four five) and symbols. And don't reuse them across different accounts! A password manager is your best friend here.

unnormalised: Next up, be wary of phishing scams. Those emails claiming you’ve won a lottery or that your bank account is blocked? They're probably fake. Always double-check the sender’s address and look for any suspicious links before clicking on anything. Never, ever give out your personal information (like Aadhaar No or PAN) unless you're absolutely sure it's a legitimate request.

Never, ever give out your personal information (like Aadhaar Number or P-A-N) unless you're absolutely sure it's a legitimate request.

unnormalised: Software updates are also crucial. That little notification popping up on your phone or laptop? Don't ignore it! Those updates often include security patches that fix vulnerabilities that hackers could exploit. It's like giving your digital house a fresh coat of paint, making it harder for burglars to break in.

It's like giving your digital house a fresh coat of paint, making it harder for burglars to break in.

unnormalised: Speaking of phones, keep your apps updated too. App developers are constantly releasing updates to fix bugs and improve security. Also, be careful about what permissions you grant to apps. Does that flashlight app really need access to your contacts? Probably not.

unnormalised: Finally, consider investing in a good antivirus software. It's like having a security guard patrolling your digital property, constantly scanning for threats. There are plenty of options available, from free ones to paid versions with more features. Even a basic one is better than nothing. A good one, like Norton or McAfee, costing around ₹2000 per year, can save you from a big headache.
